00056 #include "mTouch.h"
00057 #include "mComm.h"
00058 
00059 #if defined(MCOMM_ENABLE_CUSTOM_OPCODE) && defined(MCOMM_TWO_WAY_ENABLED)
00060 
00061     // 
00062     // Custom Output Buffer
00063     //
00064     uint8_t mComm_myCustomBuffer[MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES + 1];
00065     uint8_t mComm_GUICustomVariable;
00066 
00067     //
00068     // Custom Callback Function
00069     //
00070     // This function is an example of a custom callback used in UART
00071     // two-way communications when the application wants to send a
00072     // special packet based on custom conditions.
00073     //
00074     // The callback function should return either a 1 or 0 to tell
00075     // the mComm_Service() function whether or not there is custom
00076     // data to be sent at this time.
00077     //
00078     // This function is set as the callback function in mComm_config.h
00079     // by setting the MCOMM_CUSTOM_CALLBACK value.
00080     //
00081     uint8_t mComm_CustomCallback(void)
00082     {
00083         #define MCOMM_GUICUSTOM_STATE_BIT   0x01    // Use bit 0 to turn on/off sensor state 'onChange' packets
00084         
00085         return mTouch_state.buttonStateChange && (mComm_GUICustomVariable & MCOMM_GUICUSTOM_STATE_BIT);      
00086         // This mTouch flag is updated after each decode. If any sensors have changed 
00087         // state, we will return a 1 - signalling that we wish to send out a custom packet.
00088         // Also note - our custom variable must be equal to '1' as well. This allows
00089         // the master to turn off the custom output packet if desired.
00090     }
00091 
00092     //
00093     // Custom Process Function
00094     //
00095     // This function's is an example of a custom process function used
00096     // for any supported two-way protocol.
00097     //
00098     // The process function should process the input buffer and
00099     // prepare to either process a custom write request or custom read 
00100     // request using an iterator function. Which iterator function is
00101     // used will determine what variables should be initialized.
00102     //
00103     // In this example, the mComm_ramReadIterator() is used. This 
00104     // mComm function will output whatever variable is pointed to by
00105     // the output vector - so we need to initialize the output vector 
00106     // to tell the iterator what to output.
00107     //
00108     // Note: Which iterator function to use is determined by the
00109     //       MCOMM_CUSTOM_READ_ITERATOR and MCOMM_CUSTOM_WRITE_ITERATOR
00110     //       values in mComm_config.h. By using the already-implemented
00111     //       mComm_ramReadIterator() function, we are saving on program
00112     //       memory.
00113     //
00114     // In this example, the output vector is pointed to my custom buffer
00115     //       which is loaded with a custom opcode of my choosing and
00116     //       the data I want to output.
00117     //
00118     void mComm_CustomProcess(void)
00119     {
00120         mComm_myCustomBuffer[0]     = 0x00;     // My custom opcode value telling the master
00121                                                 // that I am sending an 'onChange' mTouch_stateMask
00122                                                 // update.
00123         
00124         #if MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES > 0
00125         mComm_myCustomBuffer[1] = (uint8_t) mTouch_stateMask;
00126         #endif
00127         #if MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES > 1
00128         mComm_myCustomBuffer[2] = (uint8_t) (mTouch_stateMask >> 8);
00129         #endif
00130         #if MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES > 2
00131         mComm_myCustomBuffer[3] = (uint8_t) (mTouch_stateMask >> 16);
00132         #endif
00133         #if MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES > 3
00134         mComm_myCustomBuffer[4] = (uint8_t) (mTouch_stateMask >> 24);
00135         #endif
00136     
00137         mComm_output.vector.pointer = (uint8_t*) (&mComm_myCustomBuffer);
00138         mComm_output.vector.length  = MTOUCH_STATEMASK_BYTES + 1;
00139         
00140         mTouch_state.buttonStateChange = 0;
00141     }
00142     
00143     uint8_t mComm_CustomWriteIterator(void)
00144     {
00145         RESET();
00146         return 0;
00147     }
00148     
00149     //
00150     // CUSTOM RESULT:
00151     //
00152     // This is the packet the PIC will output with the above example, assuming less than 8 sensors are enabled.
00153     //
00154     //  Byte0       Byte1       Byte2       Byte3       Byte4       Byte5
00155     //  ------------------------------------------------------------------
00156     //  [BREAK]     [0x04]      [0x07]      [0x00]      [0x01]      [0x00]
00157     //  ------------------------------------------------------------------
00158     //  |           |           |           |           |           |
00159     //  |           |           |           |           |           Checksum of the packet minus the byte length
00160     //  |           |           |           |           mTouch_stateMask value showing Sensor0 is pressed
00161     //  |           |           |           Custom opcode value stored at location 0 of mComm_myCustomBuffer
00162     //  |           |           mComm's opcode value for a 'custom read' command
00163     //  |           Byte length of the packet (not including the byte-length byte)
00164     //  Start of a packet using UART two way communications
00165     //
00166     
00167 #endif
